greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array where the row n lists all numbers k for which A329697(k) = n, read by falling antidiagonals.
comment: Array is read by descending antidiagonals with (n,k) = (0,1), (0,2), (1,1), (0,3), (1,2), (2,1), ... where A(n,k) is the k-th solution x to A329697(x) = n. The row indexing (n) starts from 0, and column indexing (k) from 1.
Any odd prime that appears on row n is 1+{some term on row n-1}.

The e-th powers of the terms on row n form a subset of terms on row (e*n). More generally, a product of terms that occur on rows i_1, i_2, ..., i_k can be found at row (i_1 + i_2 + ... + i_k), because A329697 is completely additive.
The binary weight (A000120) of any term on row n is at most 2^n.
link: Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: The top left corner of the array:
Note that the row 9 is the first one which begins with composite, as 3957 = 3*1319. The next such rows are row 15 and row 22. See A334099.
mathematica: Block[{nn = 16, s}, s = Values@ PositionIndex@ Array[-1 + Length@ NestWhileList[# - #/FactorInteger[#][[-1, 1]] &, #, # != 2^IntegerExponent[#, 2] &] &, 2^nn]; Table[s[[#, k]] &[m - k + 1], {m, nn - Ceiling[nn/4]}, {k, m, 1, -1}]] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 30 2020 *)
program: A334100sq(n, k) = { my(v=0); if(!mapisdefined(memoA334100sq,[n,k-1],&v),if(1==k, v=0, v = A334100sq(n, k-1))); for(i=1+v,oo,if(A329697(i)==(n-1),mapput(memoA334100sq,[n,k],i); return(i))); };
A334100list(up_to) = { my(v = vector(up_to), i=0); for(a=1,oo, for(col=1,a, i++; if(i > up_to, return(v)); v[i] = A334100sq(col,(a-(col-1))))); (v); };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 14 2020
